data.title: Hidden Gem
data.text: Like other reviewers we stumbled on this Museum as we walked around this area of downtown Santa Barbara. It was a great find. As others have also noted we were there alone which was wonderful but also kind of a shame because it is such a great small museum. Every exhibit was really interesting which is a bit unusual in any museum. Fabulous insight into early history of SB from the time of Spanish colonisation. Much of the collection has been bequeathed by descendents of those early colonisers and is very personal. Don't miss this gem when visiting Santa Barbara.

data.title: Very impressive display for a small museum
data.text: Sort of stumbled on this place.  Very sophisticated, interesting and intimate museum on the history of the city through various periods.with a widede variety of artifacts and photos,  A great introduction to the area.

data.title: Wonderful
data.text: This museum has got to be a must on any visit to Santa Barbara. It provides a history of the town from its early days. The exhibits and photograph displays with detailed descriptions mean that a visitor could spend 2 or 3 hours going round it. When I went  I was alone which was a pity because there is so much to see.

user_location.name: Welwyn Garden City, England, United Kingdom

data.title: Introduction to the local historical scene
data.text: A small a d building that is part of the historic district of Santa Barbara.  they have a standing exhibition of hisotrical art and other materials and a changing space that can present novelties that bring the area to light.

data.title: Interesting place to spend two hours
data.text: This small museum contains an excellent collection of artifacts from Santa Barbara's past.  There are also some rotating exhibits that will keep your interest.  There is no entry fee; but donations are appreciated.  The staff was very helpful and knowledgeable.  The Presidio is within a short walk.

data.title: Interesting History
data.text: This museum is pretty interesting. It's neat to learn more about Santa Barbara's history. My friend and I went on a night where the whole of the city has different events going on. The museum was almost empty except for us. We got to slowly go through and read each of the information plates. There was no entry fee when we went. However, I'm not sure if that is always the case or if this was a special situation.

data.title: Very nice history of Santa Barbara
data.text:
I really enjoyed all the different times and histories represented at the museum. I think there could be more but those displays available were quite good.

The museum does not charge to get in but takes donations. Donate! It makes them able to do more. If like to see more prehistoric displays there and perhaps more interactive things.

data.title: Great display of Santa Barbara historical artifacts
data.text: This is a wonderful collection of artifacts and memorabilia important to the history of Santa Barbara and its environs.  The displays emphasize the importance of many early settlers and developers of the city, and include documents and maps depicting the city's growth.  A well done display of photos of literary and entertainment luminaries showing their Santa Barbara connections is a highlight.  The Museum is a must see for anyone who loves Santa Barbara.

data.title: Flat Stanley visits the Historical Museum.
data.text: SB Historical Museum was the choice of grandchildren wanting to learn more about the area.  One was taking Flat Stanley on a journey of past Santa Barbara.  We took many pictures for his report with Stanley in all of them.

data.title: Nice artifacts and artwork
data.text: This beautiful Spanish villa style building is full of great artwork and interesting artifacts. It is free but suggest a donation so overall it's a good value:) I would definitely recommend it to any art or history lovers or anyone looking for a educational way to spend 30min-1hr.

data.title: An interesting half hour.
data.text:
My visit on a weekday afternoon lasted for an hour. I was relieved of 5 bucks by a supercilious twit who behaved as if he was doing me a favor. He didn't actually touch my money. That was done by the silent young woman sitting beside him, who also failed to say welcome to the museum or do you have any questions or anything that else that I've come to expect during hundreds of museum visits.
 If you find the Mission period of California's history interesting it's likely that you'll find something that will make your visit worthwhile, including a room of paintings of Spanish aristocracy cavorting about. Early days in Santa Barbara and some of the key players are also displayed.

data.title: Small and underwhelming
data.text: I feel like this place has so much potential. They has some beautiful displays, but that was it. There is a beautiful courtyard, but they aren't utilizing it. The girls who are working the desk at very helpful though.

data.title: Wonderful setting for a wedding!
data.text: I went to a wedding this past weekend at this venue. Wedding was called for 4:30 p.m. but by then some shade had moved in. We sat outside in one lovely courtyard for the ceremony and then migrated to a larger courtyard for dinner and dancing. Thus I only experienced the outside of the venue and not the inside, but it was perfect for a summer evening event!

data.title: They could do better
data.text: We had the place to ourselves on a Saturday morning, but found the displays lacking and the flow of traffic to be awkward.  I suspect monied donors want their family history told.  Not sure why a particular painter was featured.  And the temporary earthquake exhibit was bland at best.

data.title: Fabulous Exhibit ifeaturing Santa Barbara Architecture
data.text: We stopped by this little gem of a museum before an appointment, to be pleasantly surprised. They had a special exhibit on the architect who helped pioneer the romantic mission Spanish style you see all over Santa Barbara.  She happened to be the first female architect in California and the story of Lutah Riggs is fascinating. We spent so much time in the exhibit that we were not able to get back to the permanent exhibit (just another reason for a return visit).  There was a moisture of media showcasing her work, from sketches, artistic renderings, to scale models and a beautiful portrait of Lutah in Fiesta costume. There was also a short documentary film about her, very well done.  I'm not sure how long this exhibit will be here, but even if you don't catch it, I would still recommend a visit.

data.title: Must-see Museum
data.text: Tons of historic objects to see. We'll organized and fun to see. A lot of care and time went into this place and it shows. Pay by suggested donation.

data.title: Wonderful Museum!!
data.text:
I've lived in the Santa Barbara area for almost 17 years now. Yet this was my first visit to the Santa Barbara Historical Museum. It's a beautiful museum with friendly docents and great displays for visitors filled with items that demonstrate/show Santa Barbara's rich history.

I enjoyed everything about this particular museum. It's located in downtown Santa Barbara. The museum's architecture is splendid in the old Spanish style. There's even free parking in a lot next to the  Santa Barbara Historical Museum for visitors, which is amazing as parking is usually at fee based parking lots in downtown for attractions. Entrance into the museum is a suggested $5 donation, awesome! And the exhibits are glorious!! Now through August 17th is their Impressions in Ink exhibit featuring etches by Santa Barbara Artists. Plus, their permanent collection, which contains Chumash Indian artifacts, paintings of prominent figures that helped shape Santa Barbara, artifacts from the Old Mission and so on.

data.title: Great photos, dresses & artifacts of early Santa Barbara plus...
data.text: an exhibit of Lockwood de Forest's local landscapes. We originally went to see the artifacts of the Chumash Indians. artifacts from the early days of SB and nice museum store but were blown away by the brush strokes of this artist. His oils pop from across the room. Highly recommend a visit for adults. There is no fee but a $5 donation is recommended...how can you not.

data.title: Small but interesting
data.text: This small museum covers Santa Barbara history from the very early days to current times.  While current history is a bit sparse, the exhibits for the Chumash (native Americans who resided there at the time) and Mexican/HIspanic cultures was very thorough.  Going to the museum before going to the mission or even walking around town gives you insight into some of the place names and cemetary headstones you will see later.  I appreciated that they included some Asian history and gold rush info.

data.title: Nice, but average
data.text: I did enjoy the clothing, the historical tools, items, etc...and the history and photographs of people who built Santa Barbara once I was inside the middle-end part of the building.  What bothered me was the beginning of the museum had mostly paintings of the history of the city and it just didn't seem to be what this type of museum was presented as...and, I would have preferred to only see photos.  It was a warm day and the inside of the museum felt suffocating without much air circulation or A/C, making it unpleasant to be there.  Just wish there was more to it and it was more comfortable.
